description: Nikola Petrak, responding to the city's growing unrest and divisions after the collapse of BCI authority, privately proposes a radical initiative to the Council—a citywide, anonymous memory archive where all citizens can share personal experiences under the system. He argues public truth-telling is essential for real renewal.

Following debate and pressure from Nikola Petrak, the Council publicly broadcasts an open invitation for citizens to anonymously submit BCI-era memories, promising no repercussions. Submission kiosks and online forms are deployed citywide to ensure wide participation.

Thousands submit stories—ranging from hardship and lost futures to unexpected kindness and defiance—published daily in forums and gathering spots citywide. Public discussions intensify as the city confronts the true human legacy of the BCI era.

Stenograd is transformed as communities organize readings and gatherings to process the flood of memories. The Halden-Index AI remains publicly silent, fueling debate over its future, as new bonds and old wounds shape debates and daily life.

Moved by the collective reckoning and shifting civic spirit, the Council votes to dissolve itself, endorsing interim citizen assemblies to guide Stenograd’s future. The most poignant shared memory is adopted as the symbolic foundation for a new civic pact.
